title: Eos Energy Accused of Massive Fraud $EOSE

transcript.text: All right, hello and welcome back to the
Broken Business Models podcast. We are
your hosts, Ryan and James. And before
we get into today's podcast, just a
quick disclaimer, nothing that we say in
this podcast or any of our other
material should be taken as investment
advice. James and I could have positions
in any stock we may mention today, and
we reserve the right to change those
positions at any time. So, make sure to
always do your own work and consult with
a professional before making any
investment decision. With that being
said, today we're going to talk about
EOS Energy.
So, we've talked about EOS many times
before on this podcast, but just for a
quick background, EOS Energy is a
company whose business model is to
create rechargeable battery cells that
are zinc based. They use a zinc based
chemistry as opposed to traditional
lithium- based rechargeable batteries.
So, the point of zinc, this zinc based
chemistry is that um it is much less
efficient in terms of storage like how
much energy it can store for the weight.
You know, these these these battery
cells are much more heavy than lithium
batteries, but they're theoretically up
to 30% more cost effective per unit of
energy stored than lithium batteries.
So, while they would not make a good uh
product for anything that anything where
the weight is a concern, um their main
target uh customer is uh their their
target application is things like grids
scale energy storage. So if you think
about renewable energy where wind
turbines or solar panels are only
producing energy a certain time of the
day um during those times they could be
charging these theoretically cheap uh
energy cells and then when the wind is
not blowing or when the sun is not
shining these zinc based batteries can
produce the electricity in the meantime.
So that's the idea with these zinc based
batteries.
In terms of the financials,
unfortunately for EOS Energy, the
financial situation is is uh pretty
desperate. So since they went public in
this during the spa mania of 2020,
they've they've constantly been
generating um very large uh operating
losses. Their revenue has been basically
immaterial until the most recent few
quarters. And even in the most recent
few quarters, it's not nearly enough to
cover their cost of goods sold. So
they're run rating about you know
they're losing hundreds of millions of
dollars per year in terms of operating
losses and that those losses are
accelerating and they've since their spa
they've they've had to raise many rounds
of diluted funding to fund those losses.
So in the most recent quarter they they
did uh generate record revenue of $30
million. In the past few quarters
they've been generating more revenue
than they ever have in the past. But as
I had mentioned before, they're still
burning on the order of about $250
million per year on that revenue. Um,
operationally, they've had some they've
had numerous supply chain issues that
have only recently started being
resolved. Um, and the most the most
fundamental challenge that they are
facing is that the competitive landscape
is be is has been very difficult
especially in the past two three years.
So in 2020 um as you can see from this
chart in the bottom right I have the
prices of lithium carbonate which is a
raw input into creating lithium based
batteries. So in 2020 the prices of
lithium skyrocketed during the EV boom
but since then new supplies come online
uh very very rapidly and since about
2024 and 2025 the price of lithium has
gone down to uh the pre-EV hype lows. So
traditional lithium based batteries have
become much much cheaper which kind of
destroys the whole cost effective um
narrative of the zinc based batteries
that EOS produce uh produces.
So that's the situation that EOS Energy
is in today. Like I like I mentioned
before in the most recent quarters
they've started generating significantly
more revenue than they have in the past.
You know still much less than they need
to cover their cost of goods sold. But
along with that, management has also
been guiding for revenue to continue
increasing into 2026 and they talk about
having a massive order backlog and that
has caused the stock price to increase
massively since um the end of 2024.
However, there are questions about the
order backlog and the trajectory of
their future revenue. Uh recently a
well-known short seller called Fuzzy
Panda Research um put out a short report
on EOS Energy talking a lot about this
order backlog and so there are many many
questions about that about that and to
get into those I will kick it over to
you James.
>> Yes thank you. So on October 30th, Fuzzy
Panda Research published a short report
with a lot of allegations against EOS
Energy. And in for the remainder of the
video, we'll basically be going through
the main points of the main points from
the fuzzy panda report. And just um also
a quick note, we have a website called
differentiatedanalytics.com.
There's a link to it in the description

we have a free section. Um, under the

go to our website
differentiatedanalytics.com.
We also have our own premium original

released the short report about EOSE, we
in we included a summary of it on our

yeah, you check check that out if that
at all sounds interesting to you. And
now let's get back to this Fuzzy Panda

uh a few main big allegations that Fuzzy

have allegedly been multiple incidences

the fire department had to go was called

dangerous. Fuzzy Panda also claims that
at multiple of
of EOS's customer locations, there have
been reports of hydrogen broomemide
leaks. Now, this is potentially a very
dangerous gas. So, that's, you know,
potentially a huge problem. Now, the
other big issue relates to their
supposed order backlog. Now, to date,
their revenue has been pretty minuscule.
uh it has increased, their revenue has
increased throughout 2025, but it's
still pretty small. I think as Ryan said
earlier, their revenue in the third

million. But EOS claims they have this

and that they expect to fulfill over the
coming years. Uh we we have published

basically no way that they would
actually be able to pay $644 million.
Fuzzy Panda has gone even further and
they claim based on their conversations
with former EOS employees that EOS has
three different sets of financial
projections and there are certain I
guess they have the real financial
projections that they use internally of
what they actually think the business
will do over the coming years. Then they
have you know fake projections that they
show to investors and that they showed

secure a department of energy loan. So,
a while ago, EOS received a large loan

inflation reduction act. There's all

green energy companies. And to qualify

projections and show that your you
expect your business to actually be
viable. and uh and then so that the DOE
can have some confidence that you're
going to be able to pay the money back.
According to Fuzzy Panda, the
um EOS sent a misleading version of
their financial projections uh to the
Department of Energy to get the loan,
even though they know internally that
they're almost certainly not going to
make the they're not going to meet these

this order backlog, the $644 million of
order backlog that they claim to have,
uh probably doesn't really exist. And
you know, we'll drill down into this
order backlog even further on the next
few slides.
So, the order backlog includes um a lot
of customers that are probably not even
going to be able to uh come up with the
money to pay for the orders. And also, a
lot of these so-called orders and the
order backlogs are not binding orders.
They are non-binding letters of intent.
So, Fuzzy Panda claims to have found the
actual letter of intent for one of the

Carson Hybrid, uh, Carson Hybrid Energy
Storage. So, Carson Hybrid Energy
Storage is one of these companies that
is included in EOS's backlog. They're
part of the $644 million of backlog.
However, according to the letter um that
Fuzzy Panda found, Carson has not
actually placed any binding order to
EOS. All they have is a non-binding
letter of intent with and a commercial
contract is being contemplated.
They could deploy energy storage, right?
So, they they might buy an EOS battery.
they could buy EOS batteries and they
are contemplating signing a contract of
EOS, but they have not actually signed
any binding contract. They So, it's
pretty ridiculous for EOS to include
that in their order backlog.
Now, there's another company called
Pinegate. Um there's a solar company
called Pinegate. Now, Pinegate has
already taken deliveries of some EOS
batteries um a few quarters ago.
However, according to multiple Pinegate
and EOS employees that talked to Fuzzy
Panda, they said Pinegate was not happy
with the performance of the EOS
batteries that they had purchased
because they had gas leaks essentially
that hydrogen bro uh hydrogen broomemide
toxic gas and the roundtrip efficiency
was very bad. So only about 50%. So that
means that notice this solar company
Pine Gate they have the solar panels on
they put in energy into the zinc battery
the EOS zinc battery but then because
the battery is so inefficient by the
time that you extract the energy out of
the battery half of it is gone. So
because it's so bad, Hindgate is not
going is not going to order any more
batteries from EOS most likely, but they
still have, you know, they are still
included in the customer backlog. Not
only that, according to Bloomberg,
Pinegate is on the brink of filing for

near bankrupt company that purchased a
few batteries from EOS. The performance
was much worse than expected. So they
are not going to they're probably not
going to order anymore and they're about
to go bankrupt anyway. So they probably
could not even order any more EOS
batteries even if they wanted to.
Despite that, they still represent a
significant chunk of EOS's claimed
backlog.
And now the final issue, uh this
actually ties back to something that we
talked about in one of our previous
videos. So, you know, all the way back
in May, uh, in May of 2025,
EOS fired their CFO, Eric Jvidi, without
cause. And this was very, you know, very
weird because they had just hired Eric
Jvidi, three months prior. So, they
hired him in March of 2025 and then just
a few months later in May, they fired
him without cause and they didn't give
any reason for it. Now, at the time we
published a video um on this channel
going over this and we said this is very
suspicious and at the time we speculated
that Jvidi was uncomfortable with EOS's
claimed order backlog. You know, EOS has
this huge order backlog that they, you
know, tell they they brag about to

the DOA DOE, yeah, give us this loan
because we have this massive $600
million order backlog. But there are a
lot of concerns where a lot of this
order backlog are just non-binding
letters of intent or orders from, you
know, tiny or defunct companies that are

thought maybe Eric Jvidi, he got into
his role as the CFO. He looked at this

comfortable with this. Um, I don't want
to play ball with, you know, touting
this fake order backlog." And then
because he wasn't willing to pay play
ball with this charade, that's probably
why he was fired. That's what we
speculated at the time. Well, uh, Joe
Mstrangelo, the CEO of EOS, he
apparently has a weak moral compass and
he is basically running, you know, this
fraud where he's claiming to have this
huge order backlog. Any of his other
executives at EOS who question the
backlog or aren't willing to go along

And that's why we see extremely high
turnover rate in EOS's seuite. Over the
past five years, EOS has had four CFOs
and three uh chief commercial officers,
which is an extremely high, extremely
unusual rate of se executive turnover.
And of course, the most recent and
shocking example was Eric Chvidi, who
was fired after just three months. So
overall, this fuzzy panda report really
corroborates a lot of the concerns that
we have raised about EOS um over the
past year. I think this is the fourth
video that we're making about EOS. And
uh while the stock price has like
increased throughout 2025 because
there's like a lot of hype about, you
know, them finally starting to generate
revenue and a lot of bullish projections

that, you know, this is basically a

because there are so many quality issues

probably going to miss revenue
expectations for 2026. And then, of
course, there's the longer term issue
with because the lithium price has

that about wraps it up for everything we

if you have any opinions or thoughts
